review_title: Skilled longtime employees making poverty pay
job_title: Costume shop Manager/staff designer in Tacoma, WA
pros: pretty campus, nice coworkers but they don't care that I'm struggling to live.
cons: I have been with the university for 21 years. I make $4 more than I did when I started which is well below poverty level. Yes its not full year job but who can make more than a couple thousand for a summer job? HR has no idea what I do and how the job is appropriately compensated in other similar positions. The job comparisons do not take into account that I also teach daily as my crews are comprised of only students who very often do not have the skills I need to complete a production. I am very close to quitting the job and am only still here because I need the insurance.

pros: great support from upper management
cons: Hard to get any time off

review_title: Strong on mission, low on bureaucracy

cons: Salary is the same across disciplines, which is great for some disciplines--and not so great for others.

review_title: Puget Sound, a great place to be.
pros: This might be one of the greatest places in the country to work in student affairs.  Mike Segawa is the President of NASPA and the entire student affairs team is very talented. You have more autonomy here than possibly anywhere else. I have never suggested a project that someone has said I couldn't do or look into. I have asked to be on several committees so I could get experience and I have always been permitted. The pay is excellent in comparison to many other institutions. Vacation for professional staff is unbelievable, 4 weeks a year, free health care, 12% automatic towards your retirement. The student population is great. They are a fun loving bunch but the downside is that they are over committed.  Really, how many Student Affairs professionals can complain about that?
cons: It is a great place to work. The administration is probably one of the best in higher education. It is a highly respected place to work.  One of the main issues though is that Opportunities for advancement are rare because so many people stay...forever.  As an entry level person, you would best be served by coming here for a few years and then looking for a job elsewhere. You will get great recommendations and the best experience possible however, don't look to move up that quickly.  It doesn't look like anyone is going anywhere anytime soon. There are always chances, but they are few and only happen ever few years.

job_title: Office Support Staff in Tacoma, WA
pros: Flexible Schedule that allows for planning around academic requirements
cons: Often repetitive work, but not overly taxing

review_title: Great employment opportunities for UPS students
pros:
Many positions are available only to current UPS students
Highly flexible professional culture -- they will work around your class schedule
cons: Many positions are available only to current UPS students

pros: The University is an amazing institution of higher learning in the liberal arts fields. I and have thoroughly enjoyed the interaction with students, staff and faculty and enjoyed my work and am proud of my accomplishments
cons: While a degree at the university is coveted and they do provide almost free tuition for full time employment, the pay scales are far below what other institutions are currently paying.  And management, at least where I worked, provided absolutely no flexibility in work schedules as to take any classes towards finishing a degree.

review_title: They were completely unethical and disrespectful.
pros: Pretty campus.  I had many opportunities to be creative in my work.  Some good faculty.
cons:
The hours budgeted for my job were about half of what it took to do the job.  

There was lots of double talk and mixed messages between human resources and departments.  Damned if you do, damned if you don't depending on who finds it useful to them.  The senior faculty is a bunch of mean spirited bullies.

Student body is very wealthy (likely because the small endowment does not allow provide for much financial aid) which has resulted in a bunch of spoiled brats that treat the faculty and staff like family servants.  

I got a much better job with a better school, which was fortunate for them because I simply did not have time to bother presenting the evidence I have of my supervisor's discriminatory practices in court.

job_title: Residential Community Coordinator in Tacoma, WA
pros:
Note: This review is for a Resident Community Coordinator position that compensates student workers with free room (similar to a Resident Assistant) and should not be misinterpreted as a Resident director or similar paid, full-time position review.  

-Fantastic support for those employed by Resident life from coworkers, resident directors, and other campus offices

-Opportunities to create and develop new events and programs for residents

-A good balance of work duties with student life

-Paid housing
cons:
-Meal plan not included

-Uneven work load, part of the job is availability to residents, and a resident crisis doesn't always come at a convenient time

review_title: Best people I've ever worked with.  Smart, caring, hard working, and down-to-earth.
pros: The faculty here are truly incredible.  They're excellent researchers and scholars, but all share a deep desire to connect with students and inspire them to do their best.  The students are strong overall, and the best of them are truly excellent.  Location is nice as well.
cons: The university has implemented a fixed pay scale across academic departments.  While some might consider this a plus, it has the unfortunate consequence of making it hard to hire in departments that have traditionally commanded a salary premium at other instutions (e.g. Econ or Business).

pros: Amazing flexibility, interested and dedicated colleagues, the opportunity to always be learning, thinking and growing, fun to work with students and help them on their journey
cons: Workload: crunch time can be back breaking, and at critical times in the semester, you just don't get much sleep.  Administration is supportive in general, but doesn't always appreciate the human cost of "operating lean" (as they like to put it).

job_title: Economics Office Assistant in Northridge, CA
pros: Excellent community, highly supportive,  It can be hard to fill the entire shift as an office assistant so it's best to check in for new tasks frequently or study
cons: hours can be an issue if you and another student have incompatible schedules to wherever your workstudy is, the library needs to look at schedules and stop favoring upperclassmen. Everybody is studying, everybody is entitled to the hours through work study

review_title: Student jobs are a great opportunity, and mine has been very accommodating.
pros:
- Accommodating supervisors when it comes to student needs (studying, other jobs, etc.)
- Fair interviews
- Decent pay (above minimum wage)
cons:
- Sometimes understaffed
- Students are sometimes given too much responsibility and they are either not meeting the standards or get overwhelmed (depends on the department)
- Difficult for departments to hire based on experience, they pretty much hire on how friendly you are

review_title: Great Opportunity for employees with college age students

cons: Heavy deadlines in the some departments to keep moving forward, with no end in sight.  If you like a go, go, go, environment, this may be for you.

-Being able to work with an institution that is rising nationally
-The people and how friendly they are

-Good benefits, especially the educational benefits

-Seeing the students be successful at their work

-Small school
-Some supervisors and senior officers don't treat their employees great
-Students are sometimes annoying
-Values and practices are at odds with one another
